To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

Laundry worries went out of woman's life when Sunlight Soap came into it.
It is the purest Soap going.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Epidemics—Typbus has broken out in the Assiout district and diphtheria in the Kous district.
The Garrisons of Crete and Cyprus will in future be furnished and managed from Egypt instead of from Malta.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in Zeitonn at daybreak to-morrow will be poisoned by the police.
New Pharmascists.— Messrs. Spyridon Tracadas and Jean Despotas have been authorized to follow the profession of pharmacist in Egypt.
Public Debt Commission.—The summer quarters of the Public-Debt Commission from June 1 will be in the Credit Lyonnais building, Alexandria.
A Prince on Poetry.—This evening Prince Haidar Pasha will give a lecture at the New Khedivial Hotel on the subject of poetry. The lecture will begin at 9.15 p.m.

Suez Canal.—7 vessels.passed through the Canal on the 22nd inst. 5 of which were British, 1 French, 1 Austrian. The receipts for the day were frs. 188,929.53, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 6,806,633.69. •

Mahmoudieh Canal. — Barge traffic in the Mahmoudieh Canal will be stopped between the Kafr-Dawar and Alexandria locks, during the repairing and the repainting of those works from the 10th to the 30th June.

The Capitulations.— A very interesting article on the Capitulations in Egypt from a French print of view appears in the “Journal des Debats.” The main features of the article are reproduced on page 4 of today’s issue.

Mohamed Aly Centenary.—The Khedive has signified to Prince Said Halim that he will be pleaded to be patron of the Mohamed Aly Educational Missions. The Princes Mohamed Bey Ibrahim and Omar Pasha Toussoun have each subscribed. L.E. 1,000 to this object.

Mohamed Aly Square Outrage.—The Alexandria police arrested yesterday afternoon a Berberee of the name of Karar Aly El-Din, who is charged with having attempted to assassinate the bowab of St. Mark's Small Building in Mohamed Aly-square yesterday morning.

The Telegraph Wanted.—A correspondent writes pointing out that although Akhmim is one of the largest cities in Egypt, noted for its manufacturing industries,and has a population of about 45,000 souls, it possesses no telegraphic communication with the outside world. The business men of the town, he adds, feel the greater need of telegraphic connection with other cities and hope that in the near future the authorities will open an office there.

Corporation of Western Egypt,Limited.— Permission has been given to the corporation by the Egyptian Government to investigate the ancient Roman irrigation channels to the north of the Khargeh Oases. The district referred to is that recently visited by the official whose report thereon we published in our columns on the 20th inst, and runs from a point about 20 miles north of Khargeh town and 5 miles north of Ain el Hagar, from which a point it extends northwards to the extreme northern limit of the Oases of Khargeh.

Alderson’s Garden. — Empire Day was celebrated at Mr.Alderson's Garden by a hockey match on skates and other amusements, finally ending up in a fine display of fireworks, in the hockey match Red (W. Tookey, H. Tookey and Anastas), defeated Blue (Miss A. Scherater, Townsend, and Collier) by 6 to 3, an exciting game being witnessed by a large crowd. The band of the 2nd R. Berks Regiment was, by kind permission of tho commanding officer, present and rendered a selection of music during the afternoon.

Reuter's Telegram.—The report for 1904 states that the balance for distribution amounts to £4,915, including' £137 brought forward. The directors declare a dividend of 4s per share, or 2/1/2 per cent, making a total distribution of 5 per cent, for the year, the same as for several years past, and leaving £179 to be carried forward. A provisional agreement with the managing director for securing his services for a further period of twelve years will be submitted for confirmation by the shareholders. Dividend warrants will be payable on the 3rd of June.

Motor Fire Engines.— We notice with interest the extraordinary development of the motor fire engine that is taking place all over the world as the following list of orders Messrs. Merryweather & Sons, Limited, have recently secured shows. The advantages of the motor over horse-drawn engines is so apparent that there seems little doubt but that in time it will completely supercede them:— Penarth. S. Wales motor steam fire engine, 500 gallons capacity. Johannesburg, S. Africa, motor steam fire engine. 500 gallons capacity; Aberdeen, Scotland, petrol motor hose tender; Melbourne Victoria, petrol motor fire engine, 450 gallons capacity and petrol motor chemical fire engine, with 2 cylinders of a combined capacity of 70 gallons; Rosario, Argentine, combined petrol fire pump, chemical fire engine, escape and tender petrol motor hose tender, and reel; Callao, Chili, petrol motor fire engine, 300 gallons capacity.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
IMPORTANT FLOTATION.
"EGYPT, LIMITED.”
div.p: Among the forthcoming Egyptian flotations there is one very important company, the prospectus of which will soon be set before the public. The company will be known by the comprehensive and attractive title of "Egypt, Limited." One of the advantages of this name is that the company will not be confused in the minds of the investors with the mass of other new companies whose founders have not shown any originality in their nomenclature. Egypt, Limited, is to have a capital of £250,000 with power to increase to a million. The London board of directors is composed of a number of business men, well-known in the world of commerce and finance. These include Mr. Callender, of telegraph and construction fame, whose products are well known hero, Mr. J. A. H. Drought, chairman of the United Lankat Plantations Company, which is one of the favorite industrial securities is the London market, Mr. John Waddington, the founder of Egyptian Options, and Mr. Doolette, chairman of the Oroya Brownhill Co., Limited, one of the premier Australian mining securities on the London market. One or two other well-known names will, it is understood, also appear on the prospectus. The entire capital has been guaranteed both in London and Egypt unlike the majority of companies having advisory boards here, the Egyptian directors,whose names we will announce shortly, will be represented by a delegation on the London board, and in this way will be able to exercise a salutary check on the London board in their Egyptian investments. The chief object of the company will be mortgage business, the purchase and resale of land, the development of building estates, and the promotion and guaranteeing of new Egyptian enterprises. With regard to the last object Egypt, Limited, intends to promote another Egyptian mortgage company, which has already been guaranteed to the extent of over a million pounds sterling. It is needless to point out that the promotion profits of the parent company will b considerable.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Ibrahim Pasha Halim, Latif Pasha Selim, and De Martino Pasha embarked for Europe yesterday by the North German Lloyd steamer.
Sir Wm. and Lady Willcocks were among the passengers who left for Constantinople yesterday by the S.S. "Prince Abbas.”

Rear-Admiral W. West Hamilton, the new second in command of the China Station, who is proceeding to the Far East, is arriving at Port Said this week by the P. and O. steamer “Marmora,” from Marseilles, accompanied by Captain the Hon. R. F. Boyle.

Mgr. Haik, Maronite Patriarch of Bekerka, arrived at Alexandria this morning from Syria by the Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Congo." His Holinoss was received on disembarking by the Governor of Alexandria, the French vice-consul, and a large number of Maronite notables, residing at Alexandria and Cairo. The Quay Police, under Bimbashi Randall, formed a guard of honor for the distinguished prolate.
Mr. Vincent Corbett, Financial Adviser, is leaving for Europe on Wednesday week.
Dixon Bey arrived in Cairo on Tuesday and is stopping at Shepheard’s Hotel.
We greatly regret to hear of the serious illness of Dr. Hayes, quarantine medical officer at Suez, who is suffering from meningitis.
Mr. Alfred Lambart has been provisionally appointed secretary to the Under Secretary of State for Public Works.
It is stated that in consequence of a difference of opinion with the director of Khedivial School of Law, Omar Bey Loutfy, the able native sub-director of that school, has sent in his resignation. .
Mr. and Mrs. Charlws Baehler have left Cairo for Europe.
We regret to state that Miss Nungovich, eldest daughter of Nungovich Bey, has had an attack of typhoid at Como. Her father and mother have left Cairo to join their sick daughter.
The marriage of Mr. Albert Cattaoui, son of M. and Mme. Joseph Cattaoui Bey was celebrated on Tuesday afternoon at Cattaoui Bey's house in Cairo.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice Mr. Eynard Edde and family, Mr. Sigel, Mr, Hocart, Mr. and Mme. Lorderau, Mr. Curien, Mr. E. H. D Nicolls, Mr. E. Delaval Cobham, Mr. A. Beer Mr. E. Ponzo, Mr. Martin de la Tour, Mrs. Tattu, Mr. A. S. Slater, Mr. Petcovich, Mr. A. Monnerat, Mr. T. H. Russel, Messrs. Cassal, Crookshank Pasha, Nungovich Bey, Col. Magill, Major Hardy.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA
ARCHAEOLOGICAL SOCIETY.
REPORT FOR 1904-1905.
div.p: Dr. Breccis, in his very interesting report, announces some very satisfactory results of the progress of the above society. The appereance of the Bulletins Nos. 6 and 7 have gained the esteem of other learned societies to such an extent that seventeen scientific associations have offered to make exchanges with that of the A. A. S., In this way its library will grow rapidly ; it already contains many important works. Several learned men connected with European Universities and Museums have promised to write articles for the Bulletin of the A. A. S. which will greatly help Dr. Breccia in bringing out a regular quarterly review. In answer to a request made by the last general meeting Dr. Breccia inaugurated a series of lectures at the Popular University on archeological subjects, two of which have been given already, one on “The Recent Discoveries in Crete and Mycaenian Civilisation," and the other on “Greek and Arab Civilization in Sicily,” both illustrated with limelight views. They were so well attended that Dr. Breccia feels encouraged to continue the series in the Museum itself, where his audience can see the objects of interest to which he will refer. The excavations carried out at the expense of the A. S. S. Fund westt of the Victoria College were of great interest, but were unavoidably interrupted. The things, however, discovered there will be treated of in the next Bulletin in an article by Simond Bey and Dr. Breccia. The excavations at Hadra, in the Eastern Necropolis, also proved to be important as a rich series of loculi of the Ptolemaic period were discovered, the doors of which were painted in the style of that period in different colours and in some instances with the addition of inscriptions. Notwithstanding the friability of the stone several of those doors have been safely removed to the Museum. The attention of savants has been attracted lately to the connection between the Alexandria tomb paintings and those known as Pompeian and this similarity is strikingly noticeable in these tomb-doors lately found at Gabbari. Funeral urns and fragments of statuettes known, as Tanagrae were also found in the same place. Excavations under the auspices of the Museum Committee have been also undertaken at Chatby in what has proved to be a Necropolis of tho 1st Ptoleinaic period, the results of which will be found in a separate notice in the next Bulletin, Members of the society meanwhile are invited to visit the Museum and see these latest discoveries. Excursions-having been proposed by the committee and approved of by the general meeting, the first come off on 17th April last, when the members went in great numbers to Aboukir to visit the mosaics discovered by H. H. Prince Omar Toussoun on his property and who has kindly offered them to the society. This excoursion was most successful and much appreciated by all who took part in it, and it is proposed to continue them from time to time. Dr. Schiess Bey, president of the Museum Committee, has invited members to promenade lectures in the Museum— where the conservator will hold peripatetic discourses. An excursion to Chalby will be organized later on with the approval of the general assembly, also to Taposiris Magna, Mariout, etc. H. H. Prince Omar Toussoun, having always taken a keen interest in the work of the A.A.S., was invited by the committee to become their honorary president, which he has graciously agreed to do, and presided at the last committee meeting. The dedicatory tablet to the memory of the late conservator, Dr. Botti, is not yet ready, but it is hoped that it will shortly be finished, so that the ceremony which has been for some time planned can then take place, i.e., of removing the remains of the learned professor and placing them in an ancient sarcophagus as a suitable monument. It was proposed by Simond Bey and Dr. Schiess Bey that Professor Maspero should be begged by the A. A. S. to allow them to have two of the obelisks lying about amongst the rains of San presented to the city of Alexandria, and the Municipality promises to pay the cost of transport. Many now members have joined lately, especially since the excursion to Aboukir, and donations have been received from Artin Pasha, Judge Batcheller, and others.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive paid a visit this morning to the Mosque of Abou el-Abbas, where his Highness was received by a large number of Ulema and native notables. The pupils of the mosque and the teaching staffs proceeded to Ras el-Tin Palace.

The Khedive embarked on the Austrian Lloyd S.S. “Amphitrite" at 2 p.m. today for Constantinople accompanied by H. H. the Khedivah, the Prince and Princesses, besides Zeki Pasha and several other officials of the Khedevial household.
Miralai Watson Bey, his Highness’s aide-de-camp, leaves to-morrow direct for London by the Messageries Maritimes steamer. Liwa Thurneyssen Pasha will follow, travelling direct to London.
The Khedive will leave Constantinople on the 5th or 6th June by the Orient Express, and is due in London on the 12th June to attend the Royal marriage three days afterwards.
His Highness will be the guest of the King at Windsor Castle up to the 19th June.

div.head: CLEVER HASHISH SEIZURE.
1,070 KILOS OF THE DRUG FOUND.
div.p: A clever seizure of smuggled hashish was effected by a Coastguard patrol on Monday at a point on the coast about 10 kilometers west of Rosetta lighthouse.

The hashish, which weighed no less than 1070 kilos and was packed in 16 sacks, had been landed on the previous evening by a blockade runner, and removed to its place of hiding, it evidently being the intention of the smuggler to take tho drug away into the interior the following night.

Their intentions, however, were frustrated by the Coastguard patrol, consisting of one onbashi (corporal) and a tracker. Early on Monday morning the patrol found traces of the landing which had been made near a road much used by fishermen leading from the sea to Bossili. The patrol followed tire tracks and eventually,after some hours’ search, came to some sand dunes, wherein the hashish had been buried.
Judging by the tracks on the sand, four camels were used to transport the hashish from the seashore, and the escort consisted of twenty men, one of whom was on horseback.

The hashish seised is valued at something like £2,400. It will, in accordance with custom, be entirely destroyed. The lucky onbashi and his tracker come into a sum of over £100 as prize money for their seizure.

div.head: QUARANTINE.
div.p: Quarantine restrictions m against plague are now applied to arrivals in Egyptian ports from Bahrain.
A telegram from Constantinople states that five days’ quarantine, disinfection, and “deratisation" have been imposed on arrivals there from Bahrein.
The telegram adds that measures against the passage through the Suez Canal of pilgrim vessels have been suppressed.

div.head: KHEDIVE AND BIBLE SOCIETY.
div.p: The Khedive has accepted a copy of an Arabic Bible, in three volumes, from the British and Foreign Bible Society, as a memento of its centenary. His Highness, on receiving the presentation, expressed a hope that the society not with every facility for its work in this country, and emphasised his appreciation of the good being effected through its agency. His Highness has forwarded a large autographed portrait of himself to tho Bible-house in London.

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.
div.p: As we briefly stated in our issue of yesterday, Tuesday’s concert of the Alexandria Literary, Musical & Dramatic Society was a great success. The programme was a long and interesting one, and there was not a dull moment from beginning to end. It opened with an “andante maestoso" on the piano for four hands, excellentiy played by Misses Giorgina and Gemma Fiteni, two little mites, who, with their equally small sister, Alice, delighted the audience with two more selections and an encore. We found them best in Suppe’s “onverture moderato" (paragraph 3), where they showed clever mechanism and a perfect understanding of the use of the pedal. Considering that the piano was anything but easy to play on, their performance was highly commendable. Miss Euna Lang Anderson,whose talent is not unknown to A.L.M & D.S. audiences, contributed two violin solos, and for her exquisite execution of Mariani’s “L’Abandono" secured a well deserved encore when she gave a spirited rendering of “Perpetuo Mobile." Miss MunGavin was in splendid voice and sang M. E. Dandridge’s “One Flower” with great feeling and effect, her rendering of "My Heart is Weary" from Nadeschda, in the second part, being likewise given in her usual finished style. Mrs. F. Cree, who contributed two items, Godard’s "Jo ne veux pas d’autres choses” and Brahm's “Chansons Tziganes" (No 1), was also in good voice and fully maintained the reputation she has already gained as one of our host singers. Miss Helene Lulos, a young and promising pianist, showed to great advantage in Beethoven's “Adagio grazioso” and Liazt's well-known“Rhapsodie Hengroise.” Albeit having to deal with a most unsympathetic keyboard she played the latter number with all due softness and fully interpreted the spirit of the great composer. Mr. L.A. Johnson gave two selections from the Indian Lore Lyrics, (a) “The Temple Bells” and (b) "When I wake," as well as“The Lute Player”(Allitsen), all of which he rendered with great taste and feeling. Mr. P. Byrne was also very successful in his two numbers, ‘The Slave Song” (Teresa del Riego) and “Queen of the Roses," from “Haddon Hall,” in the latter of which he appeared to greatest advantage. The accompanists to the singers were Mrs. MunGavin, Mme Foscolo, Miss Gibson, and M. Felix.

div.head: BIG DEAL IN CAIRO.
BUSINESS BOUGHT FOR £70,000.
div.p: A most important business transaction has just taken place in Cairo whereby one of the largest retail drapery establishments in the Capital has changed hands. The vendors are Messrs. S. and S. Sednaoui, the very large Jewish firm of drapers in the Mousky, whose principals are Selim Bey Sednaoui and Mr. Samaan Sednaoui, and the puechasers are a new English limited liability company, which is being promoted for the purpose. The good will alone has been disposed, of for £70,000! Selim Bey Sednaoui will remain as director of the business.

div.head: CAIRO'S WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: In regard to the complaints of a correspondent concerning the water supply of Cairo, which appeared in our issue of Tuesday, we find on making enquiries that the Water Company have for the last 15 days, pumped each day 2.000m.c. more water than daring tire corresponding days of last year. They have pumped with all their engines during 24 hours of each day. The enormous increase in consumption and the abnormal wave of heat can alone account for it but that the town has had the water the company say there is no doubt. On Sunday, part of the filtered supply was out off, as they were connecting to their new works, but this was only for a few hours, after which the service was resumed.

The company havo spent nearly £100,000 on their new installation during the last 18 months. This will come into work early next month, to assist the old installation, which will gradually be done away with.

As regards ice, the company state that the price is never more than P.T. 3.5 the block, whatever the demand. Probably people who buy from Arabs in the street have to pay what the latter choose to ask.

div.head: THE GHIRGEH SCANDAL.
div.p: The following counsel hare been engaged for the Ghirgeh scandal case, which is coming before the Assiont Tribunal.
Sawiris Eff. Mikhail for Kamil Eff. Wassif, Wekil of the Dairah. Nasr ed Din Bey Zaghloul and Ahmed Eff. Abdul Latif, for the Moudir.
The Parquet will be represented by About Futuh Bey. The Judges appointed to try the Case are Mohamed Bey Saleh, President of the Court, and Judges Hassan Bey Husny and Abdul Aziz Bey Mohamed.
The accused received tire "document d’acusation" six days ago and the sitting is for the 4th June.

div.head: THE ABYSSINIAN MISSION..
div.p: Two scientific members of the German Mission to Abyssinia, Messrs. Boch and Fleming, arrived at Alexandria from Cairo yesterday en route for Berlin. The other members of the mission are due from Massowah towards the end of the mouth.

div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Senegal" arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yesterday morning.
The Westcott S.S. "Orestes" arrived here on Wednesday afternoon from Antwerp, London, and Malta with general cargo.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: (From Our Financial Correspondent).
London, May 19.

Things financial, like the Russian fleets,are “fighting shy”. Rumours, like phantom torpedo boats, give pause every few hours and the very mention of political complications of any kind is enough to make the few buyers turn tall. Until doubt is dispelled all will be nervous tension and paralysis. Of this state of things all are tired, and ask “how long can we bear this strain?

Markets are still idle and awaiting events. The break at the end of last account cleared out, to a very large extent, any weak bull element which existed, and consequently the present position should be more healthy. The tendency is already firmer, and any good news would cause a sharp recovery in prices.

As to the Egyptian market, prices there keep quietly steady, but without feature. Salt and 8oda are eerier at 33s. and Delta Preterenoe have gone back a shade to 13. Bank shares are firm. The latest new issue, the North Egypt Land Company,is quoted at 1/8 premium, and should the proposed irrigation scheme be sanctioned and the company’s application for the extension of the Nubarieh Canal be acceded to by the Egyptian Government, there ought to be a good future for the shares, of which 100,000 £1 shares out of 230,000 are now offered at par.

The mining section is still weak from sheer want of interest. Prices continue to sag away, and ought certainly to be worth attention for looking up. Egyptians are inclined to be firmer, Nile Valley Block “E" attracting attention on the developments reported from the Dongola Concession, a reef having been struck assaying, in the east shaft, 12 dwts. over 2ft. 3ins, and in the west shaft 1oz. over 1ft. Egyptian mines are also being bought at their present low level. Um Rus at just over £1 and Nile Valleys at 1/1/6/1/8 look really cheap.

Vers la fin on a fait circuler à la Bourse une rumeur suivant laquelle la flotte japonaise enrait subi une défaite. Ce bruit, d’ailleurs sans fondement officiel a produit un certain-malaise.
En hausse la Banque Nationale de 27 1/2 a 27 9/16, la Béhéra de 43 5/8 a 43 3/4, la Daira de 28 15/16 a 29 1/16, la Salt & Soda de 32/6 a 33 et les Privilégiées Tramways de 133 a 133 3/4

Tant qu'elle» avaient pif se reposer sur l'attitude de la Franco pour les protéger contre l'anglicisation de l'Égypte, elles faisaient volontiers l'éloge de l'odonpatioD. Mais à peine la France eût-t-ell • renoncé au rôle ingrat île poUectr.ce du droit des autres que voilà ces colonies inquiètes sur l'avenir de leur» privilèges, do oes chères «api tulations et des tribunaux mixtes.

On comprendra facilement dit la "Revue 'de* Débats," oette impatience des colonies eu- ropéennes d’Egypte, nous voulons ici parler do colonies .allemande, austro-hongroise, helléni que et italienne, et il n’e»t pas besoin de dire pour quelles raisoua nous devons faire abstrac- tion de la colonie française et de la colonie anglaise, — si l'on veut bien se rendre compte que, pour cos colonies l'kooord franco-anglais iln » avril 1904 a été une déception et, jusqu » un certain point, un sujet d'alarme Ces «lo- nies, en effet, s'aocomodaient assez bien de l'état de choses antérieur à l'aocord. Non seule ment ellos ne protestaient pas oontre l'occupa tion anglaise , niais encore elles l'acceptaient presque avec reconnaissance, comme une ga- rantie de bqo ordre et, par conséquent, de sécurité, pour leurs intérêts matériels. Mais, Vif ne'leur déplaisait point que l’Angleterre ", fût-en Egypte le gendarme de l'Europe, elles désiraient ardemment que là se bornât sou rôle; à l'égal d'une Egypte trop égyptienne elles redoutaient une Egypte trop britannique ; elles craignaient surtout que des institutions pure ment anglaises ne. vinssent prendre la placé des ipstitâtions internationales, et, parmi ces institutions internationales deux principalement leur tenaient à oœur': les capitulations, et les tribunaux mixtes : les capitulations, parce quelles leur assuraient des privilèges ; les tri- bunaux mixtes, parce qu'ils leur distribuaient une justice éclairée et toqjours impartiale. La politique que suivait la France, en retardant l'absorption britannique, assurait le maintien des ' capitulations ainsi que des tribunaux, mixtes ; o'«t pourquoi Alluma mis et Auatro Hongrois, Grecs, Italiens et même Levantins approuvaient, au moins secrètement, cette poli-, tique dont ils • recueillaient tous les bénéfices sans avoir à en sabir les inconvénients. Us l'approuvaient et s'en réjouissaient, et, comme on prend facilement ses désira pour dos réalités, ils éroyaient très sincèrement que la Francs ne se lasserait jamais de plaider, seule ou presque seule, la cvpse de l'Europe en Egypte.

La i,o i ville de l'aocord produisit parmi les européens résidant ou Egypte an, moment d'an- xiété ; ils crurent à la proclamatioi d'un pro- tectorat et à la suppression de leurs privilèges. Ils respirèrent seulement lorsqu'ils apprirent quela Commission ds la Dette était la grande sacrifiée.

Cetts belle oonfiance, toutelois, ne devait pas durer. Quelques mois après la presse anglo- égyptienné, plus ou moins inspirée par l'agence diplomatique d'Angleterre, entreprenait une campagne oontre les capitulations, ce qui fai- sait prévoir aox gens d'ordinaire bien informés que lé rapport de Lord Cromer annoncerait leur imminente disparition.

Dans ce rapport si impatiemment attendu, Lord Cromer no voit pas très clairement quel système pourrait être substitué au système capitulaire, mais il eroit devoir saisir fopiniou publique de la question de la suppression des capitulations ; le syst^be oompliqué connu sons «nom demeure, il est vrai, intact pour le moment, mais la possibilité de le modifier se dessine déjà. En-d'autres termes, il pose nette- ment le problème, sans d'ailleurs préciser quand nioomment il serafésolu.

Quel est donc ce régime capitulaire, ajoute la Revue, que Lord Cromer soumit jujourd’- hui au jugement de ' l'opinion publique égyp- tienne et européenne f Tout le monde sait que le régime capiWlaire est on régime de faveur pour les étrangers auxquels « régime oonfère un certain nombre de privilèges trèsexorbi tants et très suranné», dont le» principaux sont: l’exemption d'impôts, l'inviolabilité de la demeure, l'immunité do juridiction civile et pénale et l'immunité législative. Tout le monde sait «la, mais « qu'on ignore assez générale ment,' c'est que «la n'est que la théorie, et qu'entré le régime théorique des capitulations et lé" régime des capitulations, tel qu'il fonc- tionné actuellement et depuis longtemps en Egypte, il y a un abîme. Eu théorio, les étran- gers sont exemptés de tout impôt : en réalité, les étranger» sont soumis eu Egypte à l'impôt foncier, à l’impôt sur la propriété bâtie, aux taxes du commeroe extérieur et du commerce intérieur, enfin à certaine-» (axes municipale-. En théorie, la demeure'de l’étranger est invio- lable et les «genta de l’autorité localo n'y peu- vent jamais pénétrer ; en réalité, tons la seule condition do donner avis préalable à l’autorité oonsulaire, les agents de l'autorité égyptienno peuvent pénétrer dans la demeure do l'étran- ger pour exécuter les dérisions de la justice, pour rechercher la contrebande, pour opérer des perquisitions domiciliaires et même, dans certaine ose, pour oonstater les contraventions eux t règlements de police. En théorie, 1m é- trapger* sont soustraits à la juridiction civile et pénale de* tribanaox territoriaux ; eu réa- lité, l'immenité de jmjdlctioo pénale n'exbte pas, en Egypte, pour les contraventions,'et l’immunité de juri action ri vile n’existe pas dans les rapports entre étrangers ajipartenant k la même nationalité ; encore oon vient-il de prêcher que toutes lo» actions immobilière», même entre étrangers appartenant à la mémo nationalité, rentrent dans l'exolusirs oom- péten« des tribunanx' égyptiens. En théo- rie, fm étrange» échappent à l'action légis- lative de l'Etat territorial; en réalité, les lois égyptiennes sont obligatoires jpoux^ Jjnoggrs, »o tu, la,-seul*, condition (Titré approuvées parles puissances, et «Me approbation n’est même pas nécessaire pour les lois dé polioe.

Il y a donc, à vrai dire, un régime égyptien des capitulations, très différant du régime théorique de» capitulations, très différent aussi du ségime des capitulations tri qu’il fonotioono en Turquie d'Europe ou en Turquie d’Asio. Or, il est bien évident que, en toute loyauté, o'est le régime égyptien des capitulations qui [ seul peut et doit être en discussion. Quels grief- 11 lord Cromer élève-t-il contre ce régime 1 Dans 0 quelle mesure «s griefs sont ils fondés ! Quelle réforme» sont désirables et possible» 1 Telle sont les questions qui resteut à résoudre. 1

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM’S WEEKLY REPORT
Liverpool, May 18.

A moderate business has been done in Egyptian Cotton this week, and prices generally are firm, the quotations of Brown being raised 1/8 per lb., except fine which is only 1/10 higher. In Futures a fair business has been done, and the following are the latest values:- May 6.60 July 6.51 Sep. 6.46 June 6.54 Aug. 6.48 Oct. 6.43 Nov. 6.40

American Futures.—The Market this week has again been fairly active, with constant fluctuations ; the tendency has been to higher prices, and to-day's closing values are 9 @ 5 points higher than those of last Thursday. The principal influences have been the con- tinued report of unfavorable weather, chiefly in the South and Western Cotton areas, and the weekly Government Report generally con- firms them ; the market is, however, extremely sensitive and quickly responds to more favor- able news. Apparently the last day or two the conditions are somewhat improved, and although the market is firm in tone there is not much disposition shown to fresh specula- tion.

The following are the latest quotations.— Delivery. May 4.28 Aug./Sep. 4.30 Dec./Jan. 4.33 May/June 4.28 Sep./Oct. 4.31 Jan./Feb. 4.34 June/July4.28 Oct./Nov. 4.32 Feb./Mar. 4.35 July/Aug.4.29 Nov./Dec. 4.32 Mar./Apl. 4.36

div.head: ARAB HOSPITALITY.
div.p: Fifty-three pairs of dark eyes were fixed upon us in unwavering scrutiny ; it was dark, and there was silence. The eyes as they gleamed out of the darkness might have belonged to a herd of wild beasts watching their prey; but we were privileged guests of the Arab sheik in whose tent we were sitting, and the gaze was but that of friendly curiosity. We had been placed on the seat of honor- a rush mat at one side of the tent opposite to as squatted our host, a venerable old man with a white beard which flowed over his bare, wrinkled chest, with one arm he supported a small boy who played with the beads round the old chiefs neck.

Between us, in the centre of the hut, glowed a dying fire, and beside it, silently watching the pot on the ashes, sat the coffee-maker. Now and then he scraped the ashes together round the pot. A thin veil of smoke rose up slowly and dispersed itself under the low roof of the tent. The.silence was almost religious; the darkness suggested witchcraft rather than night; a hobgoblin might have sprung out of the coffee-maker's pot and not been out of keeping with the natural sequence of events.

All at-once, at the back of the tent, a hand was raised and a bundle of fine brushwood came down on to the fire ; in sudden blare it momentarily lit up the fifty-three dark faces, flared an instant, flickered, then as rapidly died away, and we only felt the gaze we had seen before. We silently watched the coffee- maker and our host, who being nearest to the tire were dimly visible in a remaining light. The attention of the one was concentrated on his pot; that of the other, in common with his companions was fixed on us. There was no call for speech, for we spoke in tongues unintelligible to one another, and the only sound which fitfully broke the ghostly silence was that language understood by all nations alike—the wail of an infant in its mother’s arms.

Salaam Aleikum’, we had been received with as the sheik stood up to welcome us on our arrival, unexpected and uninvited, in the midst of his tribe. We had been guided to his tent by the long spear which stood upright at the door and when he had offered us the token of Arab good-will—the cup of coffee—we knew that we were among friends. He waved us to our seats, and then, seating himself, had pulled the child towards him ; he patted his own chest, and then pointed to the lad with pride.
His youngest child, interpreted the Turkish soldier who accompanied us, and who understood a few words of Arabic.

We nodded back our looks of appreciation, and these preliminary acts of courtesy having established the requisite good feeling, all need for farther converse seemed at an end, and a comfortable silence fell upon us all.

The whole village had followed us into their chief's tent as a matter of course, and those for whom there was no room inside herded together at the door. The Eastern standard of ideas, which allows respectful equality with one’s superiors; was responsible for the total absence of ill-mannered jostling which would have characterised a civilised crowd in similar circumstances on the reception of strange foreigners.

The coffee-maker reached out his hand without turning, and one among the crowd at his back handed him a massive iron spoon on to which was chained a copper, ladle. The sheik’s little son, obeying a nod from his father, pulled a bag out of a dark recess behind him ; another bundle of brushwood was thrown upon the fire, and by the light of its sudden, almost startling blare the lad untied the bag and carefully counted out the allotted number of coffee-berries. The coffee-maker dropped them into the spoon, for which he had raked out a hole in the ashes. The slight stir caused by these proceedings subsided, the blare died away, and the attention of all was again riveted on us, save that only of the coffee-maker, who sitting close up to the embers, now scraped the white ashes round the pot, now turned the roasting berries over with the ladle chained to the spoon. The sheik’s hand stole on to the little boy’s head, and the boy, looking up stroked the old man’s beard. On we sat in the dark silence, learning from there true master of time how neither to waste it nor let it drag but going step by step with it, laying ourselves open to receive all that it had to give.

The silence was so prolonged and so intense that, silently as time flies, we could almost hear its moments ticking away. It has been said that we take no note of time except when we count its loss; it might be said of all Easterns that they are unconscious of the time they lore, because they take no note of it ; they live unconsciously up to the fact that the past being beyond recall and the future unfathomable, the present only is in our power. And the Eastern is master of time because he spends it in absorbing the present

Meanwhile the berries had blackened, and the man emptied them into a copper mortar as he pounded them he caused the pestle to ring in tune against the sides of the bowl. The child laughed gleefully and pointed at him the stern old man smiled and shot a proud glance over us.
Fiddle away, old Time,’ rang out the TONES of the metal pestle : it seemed to give voiCe to our joyful derision of time ;here was Time trying to weary us with himself, and we only laughed at him.

Fiddle away, old Time— Fiddle away, old fellow! Airs for infancy, youth, and prime, Tunes both shrill and mellow. Fiddle away, Or grave or grey, For faces pink or jell aw , Scrape roar song a lifetime long, Piddle away, old fellow!

Not a soul moved; outside in the dusk a stunted black cow thoughtfully chewed the maize-stalks of which the enclosure round the tent was built, and a kid rubbed his head up and down against a child’s bare leg. Beyond this the darkness had nothing to conceal; we were in the middle of a bare, largely uninhabited, desert land known only to a few wandering Arab tribes; outside, the mysterious open vault of the dark sky with its many hundred points of light; inside, the mysterious recess of the dark tent with the fifty-three pairs of gleaming eyes—every one fixed upon ourselves. Now and then, as a flash of lightning in the sky at night will expose the immediate surroundings to view, so a sudden spark from the fire revealed the setting of the eyes—the solemn, dusky Arab faces.

A splutter on the fire as the pot boiled over put an end alike to the tune and to the meditations called up by it. The man transferred the ground berries to a copper jug, and, pouring the boiling water on to them, placed this second pot on the hot ashes. We had been sitting there for an hour, watching these preparations, and it seemed as if we might now reasonably entertain hopes of tasting the results. Our expectations in this direction were also enhanced by the appearance of three tiny cups which had been unearthed from a dark corner and handed to one of the men nearest the fire. He proceeded to rinse them out one by one with hot water, displaying a care and absorption in the process which contrasted strangely - with the simplicity of his task.

The coffee on the fire came to the boil; the coffee maker poured it back into the original pot, which he again set on the ashes. He then handed the empty jug to the cup- washer, who rinsed each cap out carefully with a few drops of the coffee left for this purpose ; very quietly, very precisely he placed each cup on the ground within reach of the coffee-maker and retreated into the background.

The fire now burned very dimly. Even the man’s form bending over the glowing ashes was discernible only as a black shadow. The still- ness for a few moments was so great, and the concentration of all to centred on the bubbling coffee-pot, that one felt as if all the meaning of life, the past, the present, and the future, was being distilled in the black liquid, and that only an incantation was necessary for the future to take shape, and, rising out of the pot, become visible to us all in this mysterious darkness.
Again the coffee boiled up. Again the man emptied the boiling liquid back into the other pot, and replaced it on the fire.

The stillness and the concentration became more intense. Outside a lamb's sudden cry and the mother’s answering bleat rang out sharply in the black night, a distant reminder of a far- off world; it died away, and the broken silence was all the more intense.
The coffee boiled up.

By this time, one had ceased to associate the drinking of coffee with the end of these mysterious rites. The coffee of Cook's hotels, the coffee of crowded railway stations, whole coffee, ground coffee, French coffee, coffee at 1s. 8d. a pound ; the clatter of black saucepans, the hot and anxious cook, the bustling waiter, the impatient people of the world with only a minute to wait, calling for instantaneous coffee —what had coffee and all these associations to do with this? And so it was with a certain shock that we looked at this magician pouring the result of his black art into the cups, a few carefully measured drops only. Two were handed to us and one to the sheik. We sipped the oily black drink slowly and thoughtfully. A liquid which had been prepared with so much deliberation could not be quaffed down with the reckless indifference ordinarily displayed in the process. It was thick and bitter; we drained the last drop and returned the cups. Another spoonful was poured in, and they were passed back to us. Etiquette required that we should not refuse till the third time of offering; then the remainder of the coffee was handed round to the rest of the company in order of rank.

There was a stir among the crowd round the door, and a woman forced her way through with a baby in her arms. She squatted in front of us, and held the child down for our closer inspection by the firelight
'Khasta' (ill), said the Turkish soldier; ‘she wants medicine.’
The mother pointed to the sores on the child's face and body, the pleading eloquence in her dark eyes rendering unnecessary any explanations on the part of our interpreter.

It was a pathetic instance of the suffering induced by man, even when living so akin to nature, when he tries to superimpose his own crude ideas of beauty and expediency on to the human frame. The baby, though only a few months old, had been pierced in the nose and ears for the reception of the ornaments which were to enhance its charms in after-life, and of the blue bead which would ensure its safety from the one recognised enemy—the Evil Eye. The wounds were healing badly, and the irritation set up had caused fever.
‘Tell her we can give her medicine,' was said to the Turk, 'but it is not medicine to drink ; it is to wash the wounds with. If the baby drinks it, it will die.’

The message was interpreted. ‘Aha, aha, Mashallah,' was murmured all through the crowd. The baby became an object of intense interest; the soldier threw back hhis head and pretended to swallow, then he pointed significantly to heaven and to the unconscious victim at his feet
‘Ha ! ha !' murmured the crowd.
Hassan meanwhile had begun to fidget uneasily.
‘There are fleas here,’ he said ; ‘you must not stop any longer.'

We rose, and silently salaaming our host pissed out of the tent. It was lighter outside ; the moon had risen, casting mysterious black shadows round the huts, where weird black and white forms flitted stealthily in and out.

The Arab encampment into which we had intruded ourselves was one of many to be found at intervals down the banks of the Tigris below Mosul. We were on our way to Bagdad, floating down stream on one of the native rafts, and at night when we moored to the shore it was considered safer to establish ourselves within reach of some such habitation. On this occasion, owing to the shallowness of the water on the low shaving mudbanks, we had been unable to bring the raft right up to the shore, and it had been moored at a little distance out in the water. The boatmen had carried us across on their backs, and had returned to cook their evening meal on board. We now shouted across the water to them to come and carry us back. As we stood waiting a woman came up to us, dragging a child by the arm, who hid his head in his mother's dress and refused to allow himself to be examined.
'He is ill too,' said, the Turk, like the other child.'
'We will give them some medicine when we get on the raft,’ we said ; Tell them each to send a cure'
‘And this one says he is ill,' the man went on, as a tall, sheepish-looking youth touched me on the arm ; 'They will all say they are ill now that they know you have medicine.'
'We can only give to those who are really ill,' we answered. ‘What is the matter with, this one?'
'He has fever : he cannot eat, and his head hurts.’ I had some quinine pills in my pocket, and I gave three to the boy.
'Tell him to take two now, and not to keep them in his mouth,’ I explained, ‘but drink some water and swallow them down ; then, when the sun has risen one hour to-morrow, let him take the other one.'

A dozen interested spectators at once went through the whole proceed in pantomime. A pill was swallowed, and its downward coarse , indicated by stroking the chest 'Ha!' was ejaculated all round. Then the second pill was swallowed with equally suggestive signs. The rising-point of the sun was indicated, and one finger held up—and the third pill swallowed.
'Mashallah!’ went up through the crowd, staring with bated breath.

We boarded the raft, and had scarcely established ourselves in our sleeping-hut when Hassan staggered to the door with a huge clay pitcher, capable of holding several gallons; he deposited it at our feet.
‘For the medicine,’ he said gravely. ‘We said that the woman was to send a cup,’ we said ; The few drops of lotion will be lost in that’
‘For the medicine,' be answered imperturbably.

‘We had better send it in one of our cups,' I said, and I measured out some lotion. Hassan took it; a few minutes later he returned laden with cups, jars, pitchers, and bowls of every size and description.
'For the medicine,' he said, as he deposited them beside us.
We looked at one another aghast.
'Say that we have no more,’ we said.
'I have told them,’ he said; 'but they will not go away.’

We went outside, where a tremendous hubbub had arisen. Our men were standing round the edge of the raft, resolutely pushing would- be intruders book into-the river. Up to their waists in water, hanging on to the raft at every point, shouting out their ailments, pointing to their throats, their eyes, their heads, were the whole male population of the place. In vain our men strove to keep them off; the raft was besieged at every point. In desperation we unmoored and floated out into the middle of the river; the most determined swam out after us, and holding on to the raft with one hand stroked their chests and pointed to sun with the other. Finally, as we drifted down stream, they gave up, and the last sight we had was that of a row of disconsolate invalids, suddenly endowed with great evidences of health and strength, careering wildly on the mud flats in the starlight round a discarded heap of empty bowls and pitchers (Louisa Jebb in Longman's Magazine).

An artistic wall covering.
This celebrated water paint is made in two qualities for Inside and Outside work

HALL’S SANITARY WASHABLE DISTEMPER is rapidly superseding wall papers in all tastefully furnished homes. It is made in 70 artistic tints, and only requires the addition of water to make it ready for use. It is quickly and easily applied with a whitewash brush, with half the labour and at one third the cost of paint. HALL’S DISTEMPER ensures cleanliness, and is pleasing to the eye. It appeals alike to artistic and practical house decoration. HALL’S DISTEMPER is of special value in hot climates. Owing to its cool, pleasing colours, great weather-resisting and germ-destroying properties, it lends itself to every kind of wall, wood, brick or stone coating, possessing all the advantages of paint, colour- wash, and disinfectant at one third the cost of oil paint. It never blisters in the hottest sun, and the fact that it can be washed adds greatly to its sanitary advantages.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: NOTICE
SALE OF IVORY AND RUBBER, &c., AT OMDURMAN.
div.p: It is notified for general information that the Assistant Secretary, "Stores Section", will sell by public auction at the Beit El Amana, Omdurman, on Tuesday 30th May, 1905, at 9 a.m. punctually, the following approximate quantities of ivory, rubber and cotton:--
Kantars 43 1/2 Aal No. 1 10 Aal No. 9 1 Kling 3 Bar more than 10 rottles —- 1/2 Bar less than 10 rottles -- 1/4 Khorda 5 Mashmus 13 Rubber 3 Cotton ginned 2 1/2 Cotton with seed 16 Cotton seed.

The ivory will be sold in suitable lots at the rate of so much per kantar. Immature ivory acquired under the Section 17 of the Ordinance for the Preservation of Wild Animals and Birds 1903 is sold under condition that same is not resold in the Sudan and most be exported ex-Sudan within one month from date of purchase and a permit will be issued at time of purchase.

Ten per cent of the value must be paid by the purchaser at the conclusion of the auction and the balance within 5 days from the above date after which period it will remain at purchaser’s risk and subject to a demurrage, charge of 100 milliemes for each kantar per diem until whole stock is removed.
None of the articles sold can be removed before the whole of the purchase money has been paid.
The Government does not bind itself to accept the highest or any offer.
Signed: D. K. E. Hall
Kaimakam,
Assistant Secretary "Stores."

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Two vacancies exist in the Sudan Medical Department for two qualified Doctors of Egyptian or Syrian nationality (Mohammedan preffered).

Salary for the first two years L.E. 240 a year with an increase of L.E. 24 after two years' satisfactory service. And subsequent periodical increases according to the Regulations in force at the time being.
After one year's satisfactory probation suitable candidates will be given the option of being placed on the permanent list and coming under the Government Pension scheme
The probationary year will count towards service for Pension
Candidates should be unmarried, healthy, and under 26 years of age

The appointment is subject to the general Government Regulations in force at the time being as regards leave, travelling allowance and matters of discipline; two months' leave is given every year as far as possible

Testimonials (not more than three)- one, if possible, from an English official- may be sent to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum, not later than 31st May 1905 with a letter of application in the cadidate's own handwritting, stating his qualification and his appointments since becoming qualified.
